HealthHealth CanadaImportation of US-Labelled Vecuronium Bromide for Injection due to Shortage of Neuromuscular Blocker Products - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-29https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72901a-eng.phpIssue; Who is affected; Report health or safety concerns; ImagesThere is an unprecedented demand and shortage of neuromuscular blocker (NMB) products in Canada as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the medical necessity of NMBs, Health Canada has added US-labelled Vecuronium Bromide for Injection 10mg in a fliptop vial (1 mg/mL when reconstituted to 10 mL) to the List of Drugs for Exceptional Importation and Sale.Main Covid-19 contentHealthcare Professionals

HealthHealth CanadaImportation of US-Labelled Pancuronium Bromide Injection Due to Shortage of Neuromuscular Blocker Products - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-29https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72911a-eng.phpIssue; Who is affected; Report health or safety concerns; ImagesThere is an unprecedented demand and shortage of neuromuscular blocker (NMB) products in Canada as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.Pancuronium Bromide Injection, USP is a non-depolarizing NMB agent that is not authorized for use in Canada; however, Health Canada has permitted the exceptional importation and sale of this US-labelled product to mitigate shortages of NMB products in Canada.Main Covid-19 contentHealthcare Professionals

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

HealthHealth CanadaChloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can have serious side effects. These drugs should be used only under the supervision of a physician. - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-25https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72885a-eng.phpSummary; Issue; What you should do; What industry professionals should do; Media enquiries; Public enquiriesOttawa – Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine may cause serious side effects, including serious heart rhythm problems. The risk of these side effects may increase at higher doses, or if the drugs are used in combination with other drugs, such as the antibiotic azithromycin. Patients should use these drugs only under the supervision of a physician. Health Canada is concerned that some people may be directly buying and using chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine to prevent or treat COVID-19 without a prescription.Main Covid-19 contentGeneral Public

Béké-Bobo, a therapeutic teddy bear with a mission to soothe children in pain.; BI Pure Water keeps water primed for a better future; Biba technology makes playgrounds even more fun for children; Business introductions and market intelligence fuel consultancy’s growth; Canadian award-winning icewine pleases palates in world markets; Canadian company fuels future of flight; Canadian honey leaves its mark in space, and on Earth; CarbonCure Technologies strengthens concrete and the fight against global warming; Circle of life from Bangladesh to Canada leads to success in Prince Edward Island; Cirque Éloize: Its playground is the whole planet!; Clearwater Seafoods ships Atlantic Canada flavours to the world; Cypher Environmental looks to broaden its export reach to the world; Dr. Oetker’s $200-million investment in Canada spurs exports; Duha Group helps the world find its colours; Enbala helps the world energize efficiently; Fredericton’s C-Therm Technologies helps NASA and the U.S. Navy measure heat; Funding programs help entrepreneur expand to Europe; Halifax company helps illuminate the world with smart streetlights; Halifax photo booth finds international success in a snap; Manitoba pork exporter sets sights on expanding Asian trade success; Masitek Instruments taps Canada’s diversity when going global; Measurand sensors help keep people safe across the globe; Metamaterial Technologies finds sweet spot for science in Nova Scotia; Montreal company’s portable water pumps help wildland firefighters around the world; Motion Metrics International detects further market opportunities abroad; Networking gives food business the sweet taste of success; New Brunswick company feeds pets around the world like royalty; Northern Light Technologies illuminates global mining; Pacific Rim Distributors brings tasty Canadian craft beer to thirsty Asian markets; Trade deals level out international playing field for Canadian produce; Trade mission connects businesswoman with a multinational buyer; Turning propane into plastics and creating jobs in Alberta; Vancouver company leads clean energy movement for a better future; Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Women to watch; 7shifts helps restaurants and staff manage shift work; A diamond from the Northwest Territories that is a cut above the rest; Asian and European markets teem with opportunity for Canada’s northern fisheries; Béké-Bobo, a therapeutic teddy bear with a mission to soothe children in pain.; BI Pure Water keeps water primed for a better future; Biba technology makes playgrounds even more fun for children; Business introductions and market intelligence fuel consultancy’s growth; Canadian award-winning icewine pleases palates in world markets; Canadian company fuels future of flight; Canadian honey leaves its mark in space, and on Earth; CarbonCure Technologies strengthens concrete and the fight against global warming; Circle of life from Bangladesh to Canada leads to success in Prince Edward Island; Cirque Éloize: Its playground is the whole planet!; Clearwater Seafoods ships Atlantic Canada flavours to the world; Cypher Environmental looks to broaden its export reach to the world; Dr. Oetker’s $200-million investment in Canada spurs exports; Duha Group helps the world find its colours; Enbala helps the world energize efficiently; eSight designs and manufactures electronic eyewear for people with severe vision loss.; Family-owned cherry producer Jealous Fruits is exporting sweetness to the world; First-ever Canadian LGBTQ2 trade mission; Fredericton’s C-Therm Technologies helps NASA and the U.S. Navy measure heat; Funding programs help entrepreneur expand to Europe; Halifax company helps illuminate the world with smart streetlights; Halifax photo booth finds international success in a snap; HUDSON Boat Works rides wave of success in global markets; Kayak Distribution sees opportunities in turbulent trade waters; Laipac connects the world with its locator devices; Laughing Lichen introduces northern Canada wildcraft products to overseas markets; Manitoba pork exporter sets sights on expanding Asian trade success; Masitek Instruments taps Canada’s diversity when going global; Measurand sensors help keep people safe across the globe; Metamaterial Technologies finds sweet spot for science in Nova Scotia; Montreal company’s portable water pumps help wildland firefighters around the world; Motion Metrics International detects further market opportunities abroad; Networking gives food business the sweet taste of success; New Brunswick company feeds pets around the world like royalty; Northern Light Technologies illuminates global mining; Pacific Rim Distributors brings tasty Canadian craft beer to thirsty Asian markets; Perfume entrepreneur pays it forward; Rackam’s solar thermal solutions warm up international industry; Saskatchewan sisters take culinary camelina oil and gourmet chickpea snacks to new markets; Shimco innovates to seek new international markets; Singapore’s Agrocorp seeds jobs in Canada with $50-million of direct investment; Small business export success charges battery development in Halifax; SodaStream makes countertop bubbly water sustainable and healthy; Sous vide slow-cooker innovates with Spanish flair in Canada; StackAdapt shows global reach with online advertising innovation; Steamworks’ place at the European table proves that this Canadian company can hold its own in the international market.; Trade deals level out international playing field for Canadian produce; Trade mission connects businesswoman with a multinational buyer; Turning propane into plastics and creating jobs in Alberta; Vancouver company leads clean energy movement for a better future; Vancouver’s Kryton helps to make buildings more durable around the world; Vivo Team taps people-performance data to improve workplace soft skills; Winnipeg company’s ‘weather in a box’ technology helps feed the world; With Newfoundland’s AbbyShot Clothiers, you can dress like your favourite movie character; Workplace explosions just another day at Powertech Labs; Focusing on Nicaragua's next generation; Empowering women and youth in Egypt; WASHing practices in Ghana improve family health; Community initiatives feed school children in Kenya; Restoring the lives of human trafficking survivors in Ukraine; Canada supports Food for Literacy to empower young girls; Latrines and tippy taps help more girls attend school in Ghana; Improving basic health care services in northern Afghanistan; Canada helps improve access to livelihoods and water for communities in northern Ghana; Building gender equality in the Afghanistan police force; Helping local communities build trust in Mali; Canada champions LGBTQ2 rights across Asia-Pacific; Canada Day celebration in Chile highlights Diversity and Inclusion; Promoting freedom of the press in South Sudan; Breaking down barriers to celebrate LGBTI rights in Kazakhstan; In Tanzania, film is a powerful tool to end FGM; It takes a village: Addressing child, early and forced marriage in Côte d’Ivoire; Something to smile and sing about; “This is one of my favorite moments of the day”: School meals in Niger; “This is a new Afghanistan”: Women won’t be silenced; The women of the municipal police services of Lebanon are there to stay; The chance to be a kid: protecting Colombian children in armed conflict; Access to justice: A big step for Malian women; “Feere diyara” (marketing has been good) for Sabati; Irrigation for food, better health, jobs and bringing people together; Family and community medicine: An asset in isolated regions of Mali; Dialogue, truth and reconciliation: The long road to peace in Mali; #FemParl IV: Inspiring action from the Middle East to South and Southeast Asia!; Did you know mathematics can help cocoa farmers adapt to the changing climate?; Building a National Textbook and Book Industry; Inclusive finance reaching financially excluded persons in Mali; Textbooks for Malian students; Local irrigation: Improving water management to boost agriculture and reduce poverty; In Mali: giving textbooks new life; SOLAR: A high-quality cold chain to improve the health of Mali's mothers and children; Canadian Support for the National Policy on Gender: Improving the Lives of Mali’s Women; SIGTAS: The Key to Modernizing Tax Administration in Mali; Office of the Auditor General of Mali; Grain commercialization by Malian cooperatives: A Market of the Future; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Canada and the worldGlobal Affairs CanadaThe Canada Fund for Local Initiatives - Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africaen2020-05-05https://www.international.gc.ca/world-monde/funding-financement/cfli-fcil/2020/south_africa-afrique_du_sud.aspx?lang=engProgram Description ; How to apply; General Information; Organizations eligible to apply for CFLI funding ; Thematic priorities ; COVID-19 Crisis ; Gender-based analysis  ; Eligible costsThe CFLI is a program designed to support small-scale, high-impact projects in developing countries that align with Global Affairs Canada’s thematic priority areas for engagement. The program is directed at projects conceived and designed predominantly by local partners. Projects are selected and approved by the relevant Canadian embassy or high commission. The CFLI also serves to support positive bilateral relations between Canada and recipient countries and their civil societies by deepening contacts and supporting local endeavours.Main Covid-19 content

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaMigratory Game Bird Hunting Permiten2020-05-04https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-game-bird-hunting/permit.htmlNoticeThe Migratory Game Bird Hunting Permits are now available for the 2015 hunting season and are valid until March 10th, 2016 during open season (also valid until July 31st, 2016 for specified overabundant species). Environment Canada is pleased to announce that starting this year a full electronic permitting system will enable Canadian and international hunters to buy permits online and print them from home. Permits are also available for purchase at Canada Post outlets and through some independent vendors. If you have any questions with regards to the availability of the Migratory Game Bird Hunting Permits at a postal outlet, you can contact Canada Post customer service at 1-866-607-6301.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicMigratory Game Bird Hunting Permit

Canadian Support for the National Policy on Gender: Improving the Lives of Mali’s Women; SIGTAS: The Key to Modernizing Tax Administration in Mali; Office of the Auditor General of Mali; Grain commercialization by Malian cooperatives: A Market of the Future; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

N/ACanada Revenue AgencyDeferral of GST/HST Tax Remittances (COVID-19 Measures)4431en2020-05-20https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/campaigns/covid-19-update/frequently-asked-questions-gst-hst.htmlOn this page; 1. What fiscal measures is the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) taking to help Canadian businesses manage their GST/HST payments and remittances?; 2. I am an annual filer who is required to make quarterly GST/HST instalment payments. Does the announced deferral apply to instalment payments?; 3. I am an individual with a calendar year reporting period who is not required to file my GST/HST return until June 15th. Am I still required to remit the net tax owing for my 2019 reporting period by April 30, 2020.; 4. The Government has now announced temporary payment deferrals for income tax, GST/HST and Customs duties. Will there be a similar deferral for excise taxes and duties?; 5. Will my GST/HST return be processed if I file it electronically?; 6. Will my GST/HST return be processed if I mail in a paper copy?; 7. If I am expecting a refund after filing my GST/HST return, will my refund still be processed and issued?; 8. Who can I contact to get more information on my GST/HST account during this pandemic?; 9. Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Canada’s food supplyIn today's interconnected global business climate, the new coronavirus (or COVID 19) is affecting the way Canadian companies operate. Efforts to control and mitigate the spread of the virus include travel restrictions and temporary border restrictions. These efforts could have further implications on international business development activities.Main Covid-19 content

They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Women to watch; 7shifts helps restaurants and staff manage shift work; A diamond from the Northwest Territories that is a cut above the rest; Asian and European markets teem with opportunity for Canada’s northern fisheries; Béké-Bobo, a therapeutic teddy bear with a mission to soothe children in pain.; BI Pure Water keeps water primed for a better future; Biba technology makes playgrounds even more fun for children; Business introductions and market intelligence fuel consultancy’s growth; Canadian award-winning icewine pleases palates in world markets; Canadian company fuels future of flight; Canadian honey leaves its mark in space, and on Earth; CarbonCure Technologies strengthens concrete and the fight against global warming; Circle of life from Bangladesh to Canada leads to success in Prince Edward Island; Cirque Éloize: Its playground is the whole planet!; Clearwater Seafoods ships Atlantic Canada flavours to the world; Cypher Environmental looks to broaden its export reach to the world; Dr. Oetker’s $200-million investment in Canada spurs exports; Duha Group helps the world find its colours; Enbala helps the world energize efficiently; eSight designs and manufactures electronic eyewear for people with severe vision loss.; Family-owned cherry producer Jealous Fruits is exporting sweetness to the world; First-ever Canadian LGBTQ2 trade mission; Fredericton’s C-Therm Technologies helps NASA and the U.S. Navy measure heat; Funding programs help entrepreneur expand to Europe; Halifax company helps illuminate the world with smart streetlights; Halifax photo booth finds international success in a snap; HUDSON Boat Works rides wave of success in global markets; Kayak Distribution sees opportunities in turbulent trade waters; Laipac connects the world with its locator devices; Laughing Lichen introduces northern Canada wildcraft products to overseas markets; Manitoba pork exporter sets sights on expanding Asian trade success; Masitek Instruments taps Canada’s diversity when going global; Measurand sensors help keep people safe across the globe; Metamaterial Technologies finds sweet spot for science in Nova Scotia; Montreal company’s portable water pumps help wildland firefighters around the world; Motion Metrics International detects further market opportunities abroad; Networking gives food business the sweet taste of success; New Brunswick company feeds pets around the world like royalty; Northern Light Technologies illuminates global mining; Pacific Rim Distributors brings tasty Canadian craft beer to thirsty Asian markets; Singapore’s Agrocorp seeds jobs in Canada with $50-million of direct investment; Small business export success charges battery development in Halifax; SodaStream makes countertop bubbly water sustainable and healthy; Sous vide slow-cooker innovates with Spanish flair in Canada; StackAdapt shows global reach with online advertising innovation; Steamworks’ place at the European table proves that this Canadian company can hold its own in the international market.; Trade deals level out international playing field for Canadian produce; Trade mission connects businesswoman with a multinational buyer; Turning propane into plastics and creating jobs in Alberta; Vancouver company leads clean energy movement for a better future; Vancouver’s Kryton helps to make buildings more durable around the world; Vivo Team taps people-performance data to improve workplace soft skills; Winnipeg company’s ‘weather in a box’ technology helps feed the world; With Newfoundland’s AbbyShot Clothiers, you can dress like your favourite movie character; Workplace explosions just another day at Powertech Labs; Focusing on Nicaragua's next generation; Empowering women and youth in Egypt; WASHing practices in Ghana improve family health; Community initiatives feed school children in Kenya; Restoring the lives of human trafficking survivors in Ukraine; Canada supports Food for Literacy to empower young girls; Latrines and tippy taps help more girls attend school in Ghana; Improving basic health care services in northern Afghanistan; Canada helps improve access to livelihoods and water for communities in northern Ghana; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Passionate teen leads fight against FGM in Tanzania; Smashing tensions in Iraq, one volleyball tournament at a time; Language, the bridge builder in Iraq; From Iraq, with kisses; Promoting social cohesion in Iraq; Cleaning Up Daesh’s Explosive Legacy in Iraq; Empowering young Egyptian women to be entrepreneurs; From Isolation to Integration in Jordan; Supporting Venezuelan migrants in Brazil; Papua New Guinea: Helping women – helping communities; Colombian GBV survivors share their stories; How can you champion women’s rights?; M-SAWA project empowers small entrepreneurs: Gloria’s story; Shipping stability in a box to Iraq; Turning words to action in India’s fight for transgender rights; Food security in West Africa: a geographical issue; M-SAWA project: Kwale coconuts; Women activists fight to bridge the WikiGap; From Syria to the stage: Diana’s story; Sowing seeds for gender equality through agriculture in Côte d’Ivoire; Building gender equality in the Afghanistan police force; Helping local communities build trust in Mali; Canada champions LGBTQ2 rights across Asia-Pacific; Canada Day celebration in Chile highlights Diversity and Inclusion; Promoting freedom of the press in South Sudan; Breaking down barriers to celebrate LGBTI rights in Kazakhstan; In Tanzania, film is a powerful tool to end FGM; It takes a village: Addressing child, early and forced marriage in Côte d’Ivoire; Something to smile and sing about; “This is one of my favorite moments of the day”: School meals in Niger; “This is a new Afghanistan”: Women won’t be silenced; The women of the municipal police services of Lebanon are there to stay; The chance to be a kid: protecting Colombian children in armed conflict; Access to justice: A big step for Malian women; “Feere diyara” (marketing has been good) for Sabati; Irrigation for food, better health, jobs and bringing people together; Family and community medicine: An asset in isolated regions of Mali; Dialogue, truth and reconciliation: The long road to peace in Mali; #FemParl IV: Inspiring action from the Middle East to South and Southeast Asia!; Did you know mathematics can help cocoa farmers adapt to the changing climate?; Building a National Textbook and Book Industry; Inclusive finance reaching financially excluded persons in Mali; Textbooks for Malian students; Local irrigation: Improving water management to boost agriculture and reduce poverty; In Mali: giving textbooks new life; SOLAR: A high-quality cold chain to improve the health of Mali's mothers and children; Canadian Support for the National Policy on Gender: Improving the Lives of Mali’s Women; SIGTAS: The Key to Modernizing Tax Administration in Mali; Office of the Auditor General of Mali; Grain commercialization by Malian cooperatives: A Market of the Future; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

HealthHealth CanadaImportation of US-Labelled Rocuronium Bromide Injection Due to Shortage of Canadian-labelled Rocuronium - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-05-01https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72907a-eng.phpIssue; Who is affected; Report health or safety concerns; ImagesThere is an unprecedented demand and shortage of Rocuronium Bromide Injection in Canada as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the medical necessity of this product, Health Canada has added US-labelled Rocuronium Bromide Injection 100 mg/10 mL (10 mg/mL) vials in a 10 mL volume to the List of Drugs for Exceptional Importation and Sale in accordance with the Interim Order.Main Covid-19 contentHealthcare Professionals

If so, what type of expense is included and to whom do these apply?; Question 9: Does the guidance set a time limit for eligibility of expenditures related to the repatriation of project staff and their dependants, volunteers, interns and students?; Question 10: Are safety kits and safety equipment eligible costs?; Question 11: Once repatriated, if volunteers are able to resume their contribution to the project, will the deemed daily value already established for the purpose of the recipient organization’s cost share continue to count as their in-kind contribution?; Question 12: Once repatriated, if volunteers are able to resume their contributions to the project, will an overhead allowance of 12% of a deemed $200 per day value continue to be paid to the recipient organization?; Question 13: By when must recipient organizations communicate with their respective GAC project officer about their reassessment of the project’s feasibility?; Question 14: What happens if project activities are not resumed within the 30-working-day period and the Canadian partner must lay off staff in a country that legally requires a certain length of time between the issuance of a layoff notice and the end of employment?; Question 15: Is the flexibility offered through the guidance only applicable to COVID-19-crisis-related costs?; Question 16: What flexibility can be offered without amending the contribution agreement?; Question 17: Can a recipient organization that currently has an operational contribution agreement with GAC modify certain project activities to address some of the immediate COVID-19 issues in the country of their project?; Question 18: What is a minimum amount of activity required to justify continued payment of salaries?; Question 19: Can Can recipient organizations claim costs as per the guidance as well as through other government-announced measures, if applicable?; They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

HealthHealth CanadaUnauthorized test kits claiming to diagnose or detect COVID-19 put your health at risk - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-05-07https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/73003a-eng.phpSummary; Issue; What you should do; Media enquiries; Public enquiriesOTTAWA – Health Canada is warning Canadians not to buy home diagnostic test kits, including mail-in sample collection kits, claiming to diagnose or detect COVID-19 because they may provide inaccurate or false results. These products have not been authorized by Health Canada, which means they have not been reviewed for safety, quality or effectiveness.Main Covid-19 contentGeneral Public

Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Use this form to submit corrections or comments on this row in the inventory. Comments will be reviewed by DTO

Web Content Inventory Instructions

The COVID-19 Web content inventory tool relies on data from two sources:

  • Canada.ca search results
  • AEM web crawl

We aim to update the tool daily.

You can use the tool to validate and improve metadata. You can also identify:

  • what COVID-19 content exists for a particular theme or department
  • duplication or overlap
  • out-of-date materials

Tool use examples

These examples show specific uses for validation of content and updates to metadata.

E.g. The Benefits theme lead wants to ensure there are no out-dated alerts

  • On the left side of the page, select Benefits in the theme drop down
  • Select “alerts” for content type
  • Click “Filter” button to show results
  • Click and hold the URL column header and reposition it to the left of the page title
  • Select each page URL to verify that the alerts are still accurate

E.g. The Department of Finance wants to ensure their COVID-19 pages are following the metadata guidance for titles

  • On the left side of the page, select Department of Finance in the departments list
  • Click the filter button to show results
  • Click and hold the TITLE column and move it to the right of the Department column
  • A review of results shows COVID appears in some cases, but not all
  • Click the “Excel” button towards the top of the page to download a spreadsheet of these results
  • Use the spreadsheet to provide clear instructions to the department content manager

Considerations

  • The tool is available in English and French
  • The left side of the page provides the main site filters – theme, department and four types of content:
  • Main COVID-19 content returns pages that include substantive information on health, economics, restrictions, etc. Generally, pages accessible from Canada.ca/covid19 are “main COVID-19” content.
  • Alerts returns pages that include an visual and textual alert, with some content related to COVID-19, usually in relation to a service interruption.
  • Links returns pages that include a link to a page with COVID-19 content
  • News returns 5 types of news releases and announcements, including:
    • backgrounders
    • media advisories
    • news releases
    • speeches
    • statements
  • The columns can be rearranged by clicking, holding and dragging them to the position you want The toggles at the top of the page give you additional control over what you see Use the Filter reset button if your results are not what you expected

Generate an Excel report for internal use

To generate an Excel report:

  • Use the filter tool, to get the results you want,
  • click the Excel button.
  • Use the comments column in the Excel report to indicate changes or questions for your web team, program area or communications team

This may be useful for:

  • corrections
  • removal or archiving of pages
  • adding new pages to your cluster

Submit comments to the Digital Transformation Office (DTO)

To submit comments about a specific page to the DTO, click the Submit button in the Comments column for that page in the inventory tool. Comments are sent to: dto.btn@tbs-sct.gc.ca

Comments will help us to complete a QA on the tool. Right now we see this tool as an alpha release, there are improvements and corrections required.
